title: Operation Monitoring Records
description: Requirements for operational monitoring and record-keeping including process monitoring, temperature logs, water quality testing, sanitation verification, and traceability documentation

requirements.question: Are there inspection records for incoming goods (e.g., raw materials, ingredients and packing materials)?

Are there inspection logs on incoming trailers (and other forms of transport) for rodents and insects, cleanliness, holes and temperature control of the trailer (for food requiring temperature control for safety and/or as required per buyer specifications)?

Are there records for the necessary process monitoring activities (e.g., pH, water temperature vs. product temperature, metal detection, X-ray, labeling, heating processes, reduction/kill step processes, postharvest pesticides (e.g., fungicides), control of water activity, drying, etc.), showing, for example, monitoring frequencies, results and where necessary the corrective actions?

Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial (e.g., free chlorine, peroxyacetic acid) concentration testing of product contact water and ice solutions prior to start up and throughout the production runs?
Are there records of monitoring for build-up of organic material (turbidity) and changing of recirculated and batch water systems (e.g., dump tanks, flumes, hydro vacuums, hydro coolers, etc.)?

Are there records (with corrective actions) that show anti-microbial concentration testing of hand/foot/tool dip stations, and are there stock check and replenishment records for gel and spray stations?
Is there a tool accountability program for knives and similar cutting hand tools used in the production area?
Is there a pre-operation inspection log?

capaInject: Establish corrective action procedures when incoming goods fail inspection criteria including rejection protocols and supplier notification
Implement immediate actions when trailer inspections reveal pest activity, temperature violations, or sanitation deficiencies
Develop procedures for addressing process monitoring deviations including pH, temperature, metal detection, and kill step failures
Create action plans for restoring antimicrobial concentrations when testing reveals out-of-specification results in water systems
Establish preventive measures to address organic material buildup trends in recirculated water requiring more frequent change-out schedules
traceabilityInject: Maintain inspection records for all incoming raw materials, ingredients, and packaging materials with acceptance criteria and lot identification
Keep trailer inspection logs documenting cleanliness, pest evidence, structural integrity, and temperature control verification
Retain process monitoring records showing pH, temperature, antimicrobial levels, metal detection results, and heating process parameters with monitoring frequencies
Document antimicrobial concentration testing results for product contact water and ice solutions throughout production runs with corrective actions
Archive pre-operation inspection logs verifying facility readiness including equipment cleanliness, sanitation verification, and environmental conditions
micro_inject: Incoming raw materials contaminated with Salmonella, E. coli, or Listeria can introduce pathogens throughout the processing environment
Temperature abuse during transportation allows rapid multiplication of pathogenic bacteria including Bacillus cereus and Clostridium perfringens
Inadequate antimicrobial concentrations in wash water fail to achieve required log reductions of E. coli O157:H7 and Salmonella on produce
Organic material accumulation in recirculated water systems depletes antimicrobial efficacy allowing cross-contamination between product batches
Insufficient process controls during kill steps fail to eliminate vegetative cells and spores of Listeria monocytogenes and other pathogens
